title.narrative: No News is Bad News: Myanmar

description.narrative: In 2017, 2018 and early 2019 , FPU conducted fact finding missions which have finally led to a better definition of areas of engagement and niches (where the support is not duplicating existing initiatives, relates to current priorities as identified by local media and journalists and aligns with the FPU's objectives and Theory of Change). On the basis of the missions reports and findings, conclusions were made: to build capacity in skills (inc. lobby and advocacy) among local orgs addressing FoE and ATI issues such as the new Press Freedom Center; to connect and enable exchange of experience among supporting institutions such as Myanmar Press Council and the Dutch Press Council; to support and build capacity of regional reporters to cover issues of local/regional relevance (inc. elections) and to support the production and dissemination of investigative content.
Regional journalists; general public; investigative reporters and their audience.

The predecessor of FPU (Free Voice) supported three exiled media from Myanmar for more than a decade (from 1998 until end 2010). When the rapid changes started after the first democratic elections in 2011, the need for support to the newly emerging and former exiled media returning to the country was ever increasing. Due to funding restrictions, but also due to strategic vision at that time by the management, FPU was not engaged in supporting media or journalists in that crucial moment. Even though many previous restrictions were removed (prior censorship, obligatory registration), significant limitations still remain (libel and defamation is a criminal offense, uneven market competition created by state and crony military-backed media, broadcasting still largely unregulated, huge lack of journalistic capacity, restrictions to access of government information for independent media etc).
Indicators related to the Dialogue and Dissent result framework

title.narrative: DD1: # of laws, policies and norms, implemented for sustainable and inclusive development
DD2: # of laws, policies and norms/attitudes, blocked, adopted, improved for sustainable and inclusive development
DD4: # of advocacy initiatives carried out by CSOs, for, by or with their membership/ constituency
DD5: # of CSOs with increased L&A capacities
DD6: # of CSOs included in Strategic Partnership programmes
DD3 # of times that CSOs succeed in creating space for CSO demands and positions through agenda setting, influencing the debate and/or creating space to engage.
